chunks.en: What kind of magical PCDN is the Midea Water Purifier?

My home's small internet connection is struggling with both upload and download speeds. I haven't really managed it, just blocked connections in the router and tried to guess who was hogging the bandwidth by checking upload/download speeds one by one.

chunks.en: Months ago, I experienced a slowdown, found the upload speed capped at 4M/s, couldn't figure out which device it was, so I blocked its MAC address from accessing the internet, and everything was fine afterwards.

During the Spring Festival, my dad said the water purifier kept showing a DTS of over 70, wondering if it was broken. I opened the app and couldn't find the water purifier. After messing around for a while, I remembered to go to the router management interface, remove the water purifier from the blacklist, connect it to the internet, flushed it, and it was fine.

Yesterday, when I got home from work, my parents said they couldn't connect to the internet, Douyin (TikTok) was lagging, and my wife said she couldn't open anything. I checked the router and the upload speed was maxed out again.

chunks.en: And TPLink's garbage router can't turn off Upnp. This thing opened over 50 ports on my router, and even took my NAS offline...
Who said you can't surf the web with a small internet connection? ğŸ¶
@laikick #7
@laikick Blaming domestic products as soon as there's a problem?
@tolbkni You are made in China. I was born to my parents. Thank you.
@FreddyLiu #12 It's not blaming domestic products when there's a problem, it's that domestic products are just like this. Whoever buys them deserves it.
That's what happens when you buy domestic products to save money.

chunks.en: [A netizen Johnie, who called himself a "FinTech Geek", posted a tweet on X (formerly Twitter): "WTF! Why does my LG washing machine use 3.6GB of data every day?"] IoT devices are often hacked.

chunks.en: Add this device to the guest network, and then set a 1Mbps limit for the guest network.
Previously, my Xiaomi rice cooker uploaded 2TB in a month. I contacted customer service, reported the MAC address, and it was fixed. They said it was a bug, but I don't know if it's true.
@laikick #52 Good one. I don't know how many domestic orphans there are on the forum who project their own assumptions onto others every day.
Could it have been turned into a botnet?
Water purifiers have so little memory and hard drive space, they can't be used as PCDN, right? Was it taken over to be used as a springboard (botnet)?
Tsk tsk, a PCDN with water cooling for overclocking.

chunks.en: @LanhuaMa You and @laikick are the two biggest idiots on V2EX, didn't you see comment #18?
Most likely it was hacked and used as a botnet.
Mine is also Midea. I checked and there are no upload or download records for the last 7 days. Also, how did it open so many ports on the router?
It's a router problem. Someone's rice cooker uploaded several TB before.
@mc2tap #66 Indeed, there's no need to even argue with the person above....
This matter is recorded in the story of Baidu speakers and the founder of dnspod: https://www.landiannews.com/archives/101201.html![]( )
I especially hate it when washing machines, refrigerators, and other devices that don't need frequent configuration connect to WiFi. It's like they're crazy.
